content:
Escalation Rule Entries

Escalation criteria specify the conditions under which a case escalates. We store your criteria in a rule entry.

When Salesforce applies an escalation rule to a case, it inspects the case and compares the case to the criteria in the rule entry. If the case matches the criteria defined in the rule entry, Salesforce runs the escalation actions.

Let’s break down the parts of an escalation rule entry:

Step 1: Rule Entry Order

The Sort Order determines the sequence in which Salesforce evaluates rule entries. Typically, orgs use one escalation rule that’s made up of several rule entries.

As a best practice, put the most complex rule entries at the beginning of the sort order. Put more generic rule entries at the end of the sort order.

Step 2: Rule Entry Criteria

The rule entry criteria define the case field values that trigger an escalation. When Salesforce evaluates the rule entry, it looks at the criteria and sees if the criteria match the field values set on the case. If the criteria match, the case is escalated.

You can define escalation criteria using field values by selecting criteria are met or formula evaluates to true.

Step 3: Business Hours Criteria

Business hours let you specify when your support team is available. If business hours are specified on the escalation rule, then escalation actions occur only during business hours.

Step 4: How Escalation Times Are Set

Specify when the escalation clock starts ticking by specifying how escalation times are set. Your selection here affects when the time period specified in the Age Over field begins to run.

Escalation Rules are available in Essentials, Professional, Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.
title: Understanding Salesforce Service Cloud Escalation Rules
